origination.corpname: St. Andrew's Episcopal Church (Ann Arbor, Mich.)

did.unittitle: St. Andrew's Episcopal Church (Ann Arbor, Mich.) records 1834-1998
did.abstract: Ann Arbor, Michigan Episcopal Church; vestry and parish records, liturgical materials, Christian service and educational materials, administrative records, printed material, and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The bulk of the records were deposited by the church (donor no. 4441) in 1978 and 2010. Some early records and the records of the Hobart Guild were deposited by the Harris Memorial Trust Fund (donor no. 1087) in 1940.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is not held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, St. Andrew's Episcopal Church (Ann Arbor, Mich.) records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: St. Andrew's was established somewhere between late 1827 and early 1828. Among Episcopal parishes in Michigan, St. Andrew's is second only to St. Paul's Cathedral in age. The first church building was consecrated in 1838, but by 1855, the congregation had outgrown these facilities and plans were begun for a new "early English," stone church. Consecrated in 1867, St. Andrew's is the oldest church building in continual use in Ann Arbor. A tower, a chapel wing, and an apse were added in the latter part of the nineteenth century. A parish hall, housing a chapel, class and meeting rooms, and offices, was added in the 1950s.

St. Andrew's serves the city of Ann Arbor and the University of Michigan community from location close to the campus and the business district. The growth of the city, particularly after the second World War, led to the founding of two parochial missions which are now St. Aidan's and St. Clare's Churches.

The significant number of students and faculty of the University of Michigan in the congregation led to the founding in the 1880s of Harris Hall, an Episcopal center on the edge of the campus. The Episcopal Student Foundation, with its own board and funding, continues the Episcopal Church's campus ministry from Canterbury House.

St. Andrew's has a tradition of community involvement. The parish was a founder and a significant supporter of the Ann Arbor Interfaith Council of Congregations and is a continuing supporter of minority-initiated projects and such organizations as the Ann Arbor Interfaith Council for Peace. St. Andrew's was responsible for the beginning of the Shelter Association of Ann Arbor, which provides housing and other services for the homeless; and the parish hosts a daily breakfast in its parish hall.

scopecontent.p: St. Andrew's Episcopal Church has created a rich body of material which documents both its own history and its place within the history of Ann Arbor. The records of the parish have been arranged into nine series: Vestry; Registers; Church Programs; Administrative Records; Scrapbooks; Diocese of Michigan and other non-parish material; Liturgical Materials; Publications; and Photographs.

scopecontent.p: The Vestry series includes minutes of the regular meetings and of the annual parish meeting. This series dates from 1843 and runs to the late 1980s. Also included are annual reports.

odd.p: (some annual parish meeting reports filed separately)

did.unittitle: Notes of Vestry meetings made by Roger Barney 1971-1979

scopecontent.p: Scattered throughout the collection is material of value to the genealogist. Of particular use are the parish registers (ca. 1824-1875) which include records of baptisms, marriages, deaths, and communicants in the period of 1824 to 1877. Later records remain with the church.

odd.p: (include some records of baptisms, marriages, deaths, communicants, etc.; also some published materials)

did.unittitle: Parish register: include membership information, candidates for confirmation, baptism, etc. 1860s-1870s
Parish register: include record of baptisms, marriages, burials, communicants, etc. 1862-1875

scopecontent.p: The Church Programs series documents some of the outreach efforts of the church and its mission to the students of the University of Michigan through the Hobart Society.

did.unittitle: St. Andrew's Church Society of the University of Michigan 1869-1875
Student Directories and Harris Hall Brochure

scopecontent.p: The Administrative series include correspondence, records of pew rentals and parish supporters, files relating to the building, to pledge campaigns, and to various men's and women's organizations.

did.unittitle: Proposed sale of Harris Hall circa 1945
1949 (Membership gifts) "The Memorials & Gifts at St. Andrew's Church"
Ladies Aid Society of St. Andrews
125th Parish anniversary/30th anniversary of Rev. Henry Lewis' Ordination

scopecontent.p: The parish scrapbooks are a very useful compilation of documents and information going back to the earliest days of the church. Many original documents and now obscure newspaper articles found their way into the scrapbooks. A large number of the weekly parish bulletins published during the 1920's and early 1930's are also in the scrapbooks.

did.unittitle: Diocese of Michigan and other non-parish material

scopecontent.p: The Diocese of Michigan and other non-parish material series is comprised of records collected but not created by St. Andrew's. These concern primarily the relationship of the church with the Episcopal Diocese of Michigan. Within this small series are materials from the annual conventions of the Diocese of Michigan and a few sermons of Bishop Richard S. Emrich.

did.unittitle: Annual Conventions of the Diocese of Michigan miscellaneous
Sermons of Bishop Richard S. Emrich
Catalogue, Theological Seminary of the Diocese of Virginia 1844

scopecontent.p: The liturgical material is mainly dated during or after World War II, although some items that predate the war are included. Numerous sermons are included in this series.
Among the church's publications, the most interesting is an extensive run of the weekly parish bulletin and the church's newsletter.

The photographs are of church activities, including worship, weddings, and social activities, activities involving University of Michigan students, and portraits of clergy and parish members. There are also a few photos of Northside Presbyterian Church/St. Aidan's Episcopal Church, Ann Arbor, Mich.

odd.p: (include clippings of photographs from church and other publications)

did.unittitle: Autographs of clergy removed from scrapbook
Snapshots taken of areas of the church building needing repair and / or restoration
